snippet: When a prisoner who is challenging a conviction is incompetent, judges should have the discretion to grant indefinite delays.
abstract: Editorial cites Supreme Court case of Ohio death row inmate Sean Carter, saying that when a prisoner who is challenging a conviction is incompetent, judges should have discretion to grant indefinite delays; adds that there is no reason to impose arbitrary limits on how long a judge can order a delay if proceeding with habeas action would be unfair to an inmate's case.
lead_paragraph: When a prisoner who is challenging a conviction is incompetent, judges should have the discretion to grant indefinite delays.

headline.main: A Prisoner’s Incompetence, a Judge’s Discretion
headline.print_headline: A Prisoner’s Incompetence, a Judge’s Discretion
